awd_titl_txt: Engineering microbial co-cultures for complex natural product biosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Many naturally-occurring pharmaceutical molecules (for example: antibiotics, anti-cancer drugs) are the result of a long sequence of reactions that add, piece by piece, different subunits to the growing molecule, in a fashion similar to an industrial assembly line. When production occurs in a single organism, it places a large burden on the organism to provide all of the raw materials and energy needed to complete construction. This project will investigate a strategy that creates organisms capable of efficiently producing a particular subunit of the larger drug molecule, "subcontracts" production of subunits to multiple organisms, then brings the subunits together to create the final product. If successful, this could dramatically improve the efficiency of large molecule drug production, and could also increase the speed of identification of more effective drug molecules. This project will also expand the development of a STEM-trained workforce through targeted outreach and engagement of high school and college students from under-represented populations in the research project.

This proposed study aims to adapt engineered E. coli strains to constitute co-cultures for production of three representative natural products with characteristically long and complicated biosynthetic pathways. Each biosynthetic pathway is divided into two independent modules, each of which is accommodated in a different, specialized E. coli strain. Such designed pathway modularization allows for reduction of metabolic burden and improvement of biosynthetic performance of the co-culture strains, as each strain is only responsible for one portion of the biosynthesis. The involved strains will also be metabolically engineered individually to meet the needs of the designated pathway enzymes and maximize their bioconversion capabilities. Moreover, the biosynthetic strength of the individual pathway modules will be balanced for bioproduction optimization through manipulation of the relative ratio of the co-culture populations. The microbial systems will be scaled up to investigate population stability and bioproduction behavior under high cell density conditions. This project offers outstanding potential to design and engineer the production of complex molecules. The fundamental knowledge gained regarding the dynamic regulation of population ratios and metabolic activity in mixed populations will provide insight into the behavior of natural microbial mixed populations, which will have implications for a wide variety of industrial and environmentally-important processes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Complex natural products biosynthesis often involves long and complex pathways. High-efficiency production is challenging to achieve using traditional mono-culture-based methodologies. Microbial co-culture engineering is an emerging approach for microbial biosynthesis that provides important advantages for metabolic burden reduction, cellular environment diversification, and flexible pathway balancing. This project explored the use of microbial co-cultures composed of multiple E. coli strains for the biosynthesis of complex natural products.

Intellectual Merit. Three representative natural products with important biological activities and characteristic biosynthesis pathways, including rosmarinic acid, sakuranetin, and erythromycin, were selected as the targets for the study. Their biosynthesis pathways were divided into separate modules, each of which was accommodated in one specialized E. coli strain. Individual co-culture strains were metabolically engineered to support the assigned pathway modules and then co-cultivated together in one consolidated culture to establish the co-culture systems. The biosynthesis performance of the developed co-cultures was systematically evaluated. It was found that the manner of the pathway division, or the selection of the connecting molecules between the pathway modules, largely decided the biosynthesis behavior. Also, the optimization of the inoculation ratio between co-culture strains played an important role in the co-culture-based biosynthesis process, as it effectively changed the relative biosynthesis strengths of different pathway modules accommodated by the corresponding co-culture strains and thus influenced the pathway balancing. To better control the strain-to-strain ratio in the co-cultures, this project adopted metabolic engineering strategies to manipulate the co-culture strains’ metabolism so that they utilized different carbon substrates, respectively, to reduce the growth competition. Systematic engineering of the co-culture systems led to efficient biosynthesis of the target natural products. Under the same cultivation conditions, such as cultivation medium, temperature, and pH, all target natural products’ biosynthesis performance by the constructed co-cultures was significantly higher than the mono-culture controls containing only one E. coli strain. The co-culture-based biosynthesis was further scaled up using bioprocess engineering approaches to enable high cell density, high substrate consumption, and high production of the target products. It was found that the biosynthesis performance of the constructed co-culture systems was enhanced after the scale-up, which demonstrated the potential of engineering microbial co-cultures for natural product biosynthesis at large, industrially relevant scales.

The pursuit of this project generated important knowledge regarding the utilization of microbial co-cultures for complex natural product biosynthesis. The achievements laid a solid foundation for the construction of more sophisticated co-culture systems. Also, important working protocols, experimental materials, and research experience were generated for application in other bioproducts’ biosynthesis. More broadly, this project provided a new perspective for conducting research in metabolic engineering, bioprocess engineering, and other related fields.

Broader impacts. The engineering approaches developed in this project can be used to increase the production and availability of valuable natural products to human society. Moreover, this project provided opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to gain hands-on experience in scientific research. A group of underrepresented students were engaged in the project activities and learned critical skills for professional development. Supported by an NSF INTERN supplement award of this project, a graduate student completed an internship in an industrial company and gained practical research experience in the industrial setting. Furthermore, new learning materials about microbial co-culture engineering were developed and incorporated into an undergraduate course of the Chemical and Biochemical Engineering Department of Rutgers University.


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Haoran Zhang
